title: Ambrose Askin
text:
Ambrose Askin (24 February 1909 – January 1979) was an English professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1930s. He played at club level for <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Castleford%20Tigers%20players">Heritage № 117</a>), <a href="Keighley%20Cougars">Keighley</a>, and the <a href="Featherstone%20Rovers">Featherstone Rovers</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Featherstone%20Rovers%20players">Heritage № 159</a>), as a , i.e. number 2 or 5. Ambrose Askin's funeral took place at <a href="St%20Botolph%27s%20Church%2C%20Knottingley">St Botolph's Church, Knottingley</a>.
Playing career.
County League appearances.
Ambrose Askin played in <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a>'s victory in the <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20League">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20leagues">County League</a> during the <a href="1932%E2%80%9333%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1932–33 season</a>.
Club career.
Ambrose Askin made his debut for Castleford at <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> on 26 March 1932, a match in which his brother Tom was unable to play due to injury. He had joined the club after leaving the army. In November 1936, when aged 25, he was put on the transfer list at a price of £200; at that time he weighed 13.5 <a href="stone%20weight%29">stone</a> and stood 5 feet 11.5 inches tall.
Askin was transferred from Keighley to Featherstone Rovers in January 1938, with <a href="Cyril%20Hammond%20%28rugby%20league%29">Cyril Hammond</a> moving in the opposite direction. He made his debut for Featherstone on 15 January, but the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> on 1 September 1939 meant his opportunities to play for Featherstone Rovers were curtailed, and injuries sustained in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Dunkirk">Battle of Dunkirk</a> ended his rugby career.
Outside of rugby league.
After the end of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Ambrose Askin became a <a href="Fish%20and%20chips">fish fryer</a> in <a href="Knottingley">Knottingley</a>, living at 4 Cardwell Terrace, Foundry Lane, Knottingley.
